messages.message:
How the continuum normalization should be determined:
Floating: The polynomial continuum is fit for, at each given activity - the activity affects the continuum.
Fixed at edges: The channels on either side of the ROI are used to determine a linear continuum that is fixed, and not affected by the nuclides activity.
Fixed full ROI: The continuum is fit using the entire energy range of the ROI, assuming a Gaussian amplitude of zero; later, the Gaussian component of the peak will sit on top of this fixed continuum.
This is effectively asserting that you know there is no signal peak present in the data. The continuum will not be affected by the nuclide activity value, and the Gaussian component of the peak will sit on top of this fixed continuum when evaluating the χ2.
Detected activity, using just this Region Of Interests, and the observed excess of counts, as well as the statistical confidence interval.
(sig. fewer counts in ROI than predicted)
Significantly fewer counts were observed in the Region Of Interest, than predicted by the neighboring channels.

The upper limit is the maximum activity present, for the given CL, given the observed number of counts in the ROI. The critical limit is the activity where the signal would reliably be detected. Both numbers calculated using the Currie method.
Large deficit of counts in ROI

message.div: The age controls the amount of progeny in-growth; the activities of the parent (i.e., entered) nuclide are always reported for at the time of measurement.

messages.message: DRF does not have FWHM info - please fit for FWHM, or change DRF.
Min relative intensity to show is invalid.
Error gamma yields - all intensities are zero.
Distance not supported for additional info yet
Using ROI area as background estimate
Greater than the "critical level", Lc, counts were observed in the peak region.
The signal activity range estimate, to the {1} confidence level.
The signal counts range estimate, to the {1} confidence level.
Significantly fewer counts in peak region were observed, than predicted by the neighboring regions.
The upper limit on how much activity could be present, to the {1} confidence level.
The number of counts observed in the region below the peak region, that is being used to estimate expected peak-region expected counts
The number of counts observed in the region above the peak region, that is being used to estimate expected peak-region expected counts
The region the peak is being assumed to be within; corresponds to {1} to {2} keV
The observed number of counts in the peak region
An estimate of the expected number of counts, in the peak region, if it is assumed that no signal is present.
Corresponds to Currie's "critical level", Lc, that is the net signal level (instrument response) above which an observed signal may be reliably recognized as "detected".
Corresponds to Currie's "detection limit", Ld, that is the "true" net signal level which may be, a priori. expected to lead to detection.
The efficiency for a gamma hitting the detector face, to be detected in the full-energy peak.
The fraction of the solid angle, the detector face takes up, at the specified distance.
The fraction of gammas, at this energy, that will make it through the shielding without interacting.
The fraction of gammas, at this energy, that will make it through the air (assuming sea level) without interacting.
The number of gamma rays emitted at this energy, from the radioactive source before any shielding, but accounting for nuclide age, per decay of the parent nuclide.
The observed signal counts is less than the "critical level", Lc, so a detection can not be declared, but this is the excess over expected counts.
The observed signal activity is less than the "critical level", Lc, so a detection can not be declared, but this is the excess over expected counts.
Peak for upper bound of {1} @{2} CL
DRF not valid or doesnt have FWHM info.
Upper limit of counts is less than zero, but counts observed is greater than L_d.
Activity cant be zero or negative
Distance cant be zero or negative
